section.para: The element align declares one or more groups of words or divs that should be aligned with each other. If in a TAN-A-tok file, <align> governs <tok>s (words); in TAN-A-div files, <div-ref> (divs and segments)

In TAN-A-tok files, <align> specifies that all the tokens invoked for one source collectively align with the tokens in the other. This version of <align> allows @cert, @bitext-relation, and @reuse-type, in addition to the editorial stamp.

In TAN-A-div files, <align> specifies that every group of divs or segments (defined by a child <div-ref>) should be aligned with every other group in the alingment. This alignment is to be taken as adding to any default, automatic alignment. This version of <align> allows @strength, @exclusive, and @distribute, which affect the default behavior of <align>. For more see
Used by: <body> <body>

listitem.para: @distribute has no effect on an align that has only one <div-ref>.
@distribute requires one-to-one correlation between each atomic ref in each work / source
Any <align> where @exclusive is false may not cite more than one source.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="5"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="A"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="A"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="pocket"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="pocket"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="full"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="full"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="of"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="of"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="posies"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="posies"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="3 - 4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="1"/> </align> <align> ......... </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last-1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last-1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last"/> </align> </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The element implicit-div-type-refs indicates references to <div>s in that source will be exclusively through @n values; @type values will be suppressed.
This element must be explicitly declared for every source, even those that already have a <recommended-div-type-refs> value of implicit.

Although implicitation is not allowed for sources with any @n that is empty, exceptions are made where <rename-div-ns> is used to convert a numeration system to Arabic numerals; in those cases n="" will be interpreted to mean n="0".
Used by: <declarations>

listitem.para: Implicitation not allowed for sources with empty values for @n.
Implicitation not allowed for sources where ignoring types would result in duplicate flattened references to leaf divs, a violation of the Leaf Div Uniqueness Rule.

example.programlisting: <declarations> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng-uk eng-us ger eng-1790"/> <tokenization src="eng-us" which="general-1"/> </declarations>

<declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The element rename indicates the name of a <div> @n or @type that should be changed, and the name to which it should be changed.
To change Roman numerals or letter numeration to Arabic numerals use this syntax:
<rename old="#i" new="#1"/>
<rename old="#a" new="#1"/>
Used by: <rename-div-ns> <rename-div-types>

listitem.para: Old values may not be duplicated
New values may not be duplicated
You may not change a name into one that is already in use by the source as a div-type id.
For rename-div-types, every div type must be found in every source.
For rename-div-ns, every n value must be found in at least one div type in every source.

For rename-div-ns, if a numeration system is to be renamed, the appropriate rename element must have the valid pattern identifiers in @old and @new for letter, Roman, or Arabic numerals -- #a, #i, or #1 respectively
@old and @new may not take the same value
If converting @n numeration from letter numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly letter numerals
If converting @n numeration from roman numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly Roman numerals

example.programlisting: <declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The element rename-div-ns provisionally reassigns @n values for one or more sources and one or more div types. Renaming applies only to the current file.
This element is especially useful for converting Roman numerals or letter numerals into Arabic numerals. See <rename> for syntax.

This feature is strictly speaking a convenience, not a necessity. All TAN-compliant preprocessors are required to automatically detect Roman and alphabetic numbering systems and treat them as Arabic numerals.

It is also useful for div types that use descriptive names for @n (such as books of the Bible), particularly for reconciling those names with a system that prevails or is preferred (e.g., "mt" to "Matt").

Note for TAN-A-div users: Although this element can reconcile simple differences, it should not be used for more complex inconsistencies that affect alignment, best handled in the <body> of a TAN-A-div file.
For more inforrmation see
Used by: <declarations>

listitem.para: Every div type value must valid in every source.
May not refer to a div type with a name that has been changed elsewhere.
For rename-div-ns, every n value must be found in at least one div type in every source.

For rename-div-ns, if a numeration system is to be renamed, the appropriate rename element must have the valid pattern identifiers in @old and @new for letter, Roman, or Arabic numerals -- #a, #i, or #1 respectively
@old and @new may not take the same value
If converting @n numeration from letter numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly letter numerals
If converting @n numeration from roman numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly Roman numerals

example.programlisting: <declarations> ......... <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The element rename-div-types provisionally reassigns @type values for <div>s of a certain type in one or more sources. This feature is strictly speaking a convenience and applies only to the current file. It does not change the underlying definiton of the div-type.

This element can be especially helpful to synthesize multiple versions that use different abbreviations for the same type of <div>. Changing the div type does not affect the underlying definition, which based on <IRI> values. Equating <div> types that do not have common <IRI> values is effected through <equate-div-types> (TAN-A-div only).
For more inforrmation see
Used by: <declarations>

listitem.para: Renaming div types for a source where div type references are declared to be implicit has no effect.
For rename-div-types, every div type must be found in every source.

section.para: The element suppress-div-types marks div types in a source that should be suppressed in references. Any suppression of a div type must preserve the Leaf Div Uniqueness Rule (LDUR). See
This element will be used seldomly, for cases where a source has a div type that is dispensable in text references.
Used by: <declarations>
The element tok identifies one or more words or word fragments. Used by class 2 files to make assertions about specific words.
Used by: <align> <ana> <split-leaf-div-at>

listitem.para: May not be used to split a leaf div more than once in the same place.
Requires a tokenization declaration.
May not point to the same token that a sibling tok element does.
Must point to a string value via @val, a sequence via @pos, or both.
Every value of @ref must be found in every source.
Every token picked must appear in every ref in every source
If @chars is used, every character must appear in every token in every ref in every source
@ref must refer to a leaf div in every source
@chars may not be used of tokens that have combining characters.
Sources that take implicit div type references may not be mixed with those that take explicit ones.
May not be used to split a leaf div at the first token.
Any <tok> that is continued via @cont must point to only a single token.
Any <tok> that continues a previous one must point to only a single token.
If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @pos and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.
If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @chars and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.
If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @val and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.
@cont with the value 'false' will still be treated as true. If you do not wish a <tok> to be continued, delete this attribute.

example.programlisting: <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="eng-us" ref="2" ord="last"/> </split-leaf-div-at>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> <declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="adaptation"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="ring1881 ring1987" which="general-1"/> </declarations> </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="5"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="A"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="A"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="pocket"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="pocket"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="full"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="full"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="of"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="of"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="posies"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="posies"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="3 - 4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last-1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last-1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last"/> </align> </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The element tokenization specifies a tokenization method to be applied to one or more sources, either by (1) pointing to a TAN-R-tok file, (2) pointing by IDREF to a <recommended-tokenization> in a source, or (3) using a reserved tokenization keyword.
Class 2 files that do not require tokenization (i.e., TAN-A-div) must include <tokenization> only if the file uses elements (e.g., <split-leaf-div-at>) that assume tokenization.

para.emphasis: @which, if present, must take one of the following values

listitem.para: IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-r-tok:precise-1

This tokenization pattern takes any text in any language and after space normalization returns a tokenization based only on white space and U+200B (ZERO-WIDTH SPACE). The zero-width spaces are intended to allow transcribers to mark word or morpheme morpheme boundaries where ordinarily no space would be provided (and where one would wish not to display space). In addition, if a transcriber wishes to suppress a word space, as a point of tokenization, one of U+2000..U+200A should be used. This is a core tokenization pattern, so can be invoked by the elements tokenization or recommended-tokenization simply by setting @which to the value "precise-1". Or you may use the full IRI + name pattern.
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-r-tok:general-1

This tokenization pattern takes any text in any language, offsets punctuation and other non-word characters with spaces, then returns a sequence of strings tokenized by white space. It is meant to be applied to transcriptions prepared by agents who have given little or no thought to tokenization, and to be suitable for languages and texts where individual punctuation marks are deemed important objects of linguistic analysis. This is a core tokenization pattern, so can be invoked by the elements tokenization or recommended-tokenization simply by setting @which to the value "general-1". Or you may use the full IRI + name pattern.
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-r-tok:general-words-only-1

This tokenization pattern takes any text in any language and tokenizes on any non-word characters (i.e., spaces and punctuation). This tokenization pattern is suitable for transcriptions of texts where punctuation is anachronistic or not an object of linguistic analysis. This is a core tokenization pattern, so can be invoked by the elements tokenization or recommended-tokenization simply by setting @which to the value "precise-1". Or you may use the full IRI + name pattern.

section.para: Used by: <declarations>

listitem.para:
Common errors in <tokenization>:
<location> must point to an available document.
If there is no <location> then @which must be present.
If <tokenization> points to a <recommended-tokenization> the latter must point to an available document.
The value of @which must be either in the source or a reserved keyword.
If a core TAN-R-tok file is invoked, it must be available.
Tokenizations must accommodate every language used by a source.

example.programlisting: <declarations> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng-uk eng-us ger eng-1790"/> <tokenization src="eng-us" which="general-1"/> </declarations>
<declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="adaptation"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="ring1881 ring1987" which="general-1"/> </declarations>
<declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> </declarations>

<declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The attribute cert states how certain an agent is of the data governed by the parent element. High = "is probably"; low = "is probably not"; all other values expressed as a real number from 0 (no certainty) to 1 (completely certainty).

This attribute is taken into account after other attributes. That is, @cert is to be interpreted to mean: "Assuming the abovementioned inheritable attributes to be true, I have @cert confidence about the following data:...."
This attribute is inheritable. See
Used by: <align> <ana> <assert> <l> <lm> <m> <report> <tok>

example.programlisting: <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 4" val="all"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" val="alle"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 3" ord="1"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 3" ord="2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 3" ord="3"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 1" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile a" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 1" ord="3, 4"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile a" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 1" ord="5" cert="low"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile a" ord="3" cert="low"/> </align> </body>

<body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="4" val="all"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" val="alle"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="3" ord="1"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="3" ord="2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="3" ord="3"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="1" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="1" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="1" ord="3, 4"/> <tok src="ger" ref="1" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="1" ord="5" cert="low"/> <tok src="ger" ref="1" ord="3" cert="low"/> </align> </body>

section.para: The attribute chars list of one or more characters, specified through Arabic numerals, the keyword 'last' or 'last-X' (where X is a valid number), joined with commas or hyphens.
Examples: '1', 'last', 'last-3 - last-1', '1, 3, 5, 7 - 11, last-8, last'
Used by: <tok>

listitem.para: If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @chars and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.
@chars may not be used of tokens that have combining characters.

section.para: The attribute cont indicates whether the current <tok> is continued by the next one and to be treated as a single token.
This feature is useful for rejoining the portion of a word split across two <div>s, or for uniting as a single linguistic token multiple tokens separated by the tokenization process, e.g., "pom pom".
Used by: <tok> <tok>
The attribute div-type-ref is used by class-2 files to point to one or more <div-type>s in class-1 files. Permits multiple values separated by spaces.
Used by: <div-type-ref> <rename-div-ns> <suppress-div-types>

example.programlisting: <body> <equate-works src="eng-uk ger"/> <equate-div-types> <div-type-ref src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"/> <div-type-ref src="eng-uk" div-type-ref="line"/> </equate-div-types> <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="eng-us" ref="2" ord="last"/> </split-leaf-div-at> <realign> <anchor-div-ref src="eng-us" ref="4"/> <div-ref src="ger" ref="e"/> </realign> </body>

<declarations> ......... <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The attribute new new name for an @n or @type that is to be renamed
Used by: <rename>

example.programlisting: <declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The attribute old name of an @n or @type in a source to be renamed
Used by: <rename>

example.programlisting: <declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The attribute ord lists one or more items, specified through Arabic numerals and the keyword 'last' or 'last-X' (where X is a valid number), joined with commas or hyphens.
Examples: '1', 'last', 'last-3 - last-1', '1, 3, 5, 7 - 11, last-8, last'
Any hyphen used as a range should be preceded and followed by at least one space character.
For more see
Used by: <l> <tok>

listitem.para: If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @pos and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.

example.programlisting: <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="eng-us" ref="2" ord="last"/> </split-leaf-div-at>

<TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> <declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="adaptation"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="ring1881 ring1987" which="general-1"/> </declarations> </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="5"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="A"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="A"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="pocket"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="pocket"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="full"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="full"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="of"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="of"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="posies"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="posies"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="3 - 4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last-1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last-1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last"/> </align> </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The attribute ref lists references to one or more <div>s. It consists of one or more atomic references joined with commas or hyphens. An atomic reference is a string value that points to a single <div>
Examples: 'bk.2:ch.4', '2.4 - 2.7, 2.9', 'poem 5, poem 6:line 6 - poem 7:line 2'
Any hyphen used as a range should be preceded and followed by at least one space character.
For more, see
Used by: <anchor-div-ref> <div-ref> <tok>

listitem.para: In any @ref whose values might be distributed, every range must begin and end with siblings.
If you add a question mark to a partially completed reference, you will get in response a list of all possible valid references

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-div TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:ring01-TAN-A-ring02"> <head> <declarations> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng-uk eng-us ger eng-1790"/> <tokenization src="eng-us" which="general-1"/> </declarations> </head> <body> <equate-works src="eng-uk ger"/> <equate-div-types> <div-type-ref src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"/> <div-type-ref src="eng-uk" div-type-ref="line"/> </equate-div-types> <split-leaf-div-at> <tok src="eng-us" ref="2" ord="last"/> </split-leaf-div-at> <realign> <anchor-div-ref src="eng-us" ref="4"/> <div-ref src="ger" ref="e"/> </realign> </body> </TAN-A-div>
<align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="1"/> </align>

section.para: The attribute val specifies a particular word token by means of its string value. In the future this attribute will support regular expressions.
For more see
Used by: <tok>

listitem.para: If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @val and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> <declarations> ......... <reuse-type xml:id="adaptation"> ......... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="ring1881 ring1987" which="general-1"/> </declarations> </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="5"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="A"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="A"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="pocket"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="pocket"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="full"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="full"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="of"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="of"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="posies"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="posies"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="3 - 4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last-1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last-1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last"/> </align> </body> </TAN-A-tok>
